item.title: [SWF-645] Trinidad partial rendering not working correctly when used with Spring Faces
item.description:
Trinidad's partial rendering features don't seem to be working correctly in combination with Spring Faces. A JavaScript error similar to the following is being raised in the browser when the response is returned:

["Invalid PPR response. The response-headers were:\nServer: Apache-Coyote/1.1\nPragma: no-cache\nExpires:..."]DebugCommon1_2_7.... (line 16422)
["Error ", TypeError: responseDocument has no properties message=responseDocument has no properties, " delivering XML request status changed to ", function()]DebugCommon1_2_7.... (line 16422

I was able to reproduce this in a simple Trinidad test project.
item.summary: Trinidad partial rendering not working correctly when used with Spring Faces

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Here is what I have found so far:

The error in question seems to be raised by Trinidad's client-side JavaScript for handling the updating of the page with the partial response, and is generally triggered by the ContentType of the response not being set to "text/xml". I was able to reproduce this using .jspx templates. These templates render as "text/xml" by default, causing the browsers not to render the page correctly on an initial non-ajax render. To get them to render correctly on a normal request, a ContentType jsp directive needs to be added that sets the ContentType to "text/html". The problem is that this ContentType is then still used when rendering the partial response. I would imagine Trinidad is trying to explicitly set the ContentType to "text/xml", but the JSP "text/html" ContentType is overriding it, thus causing the error.

It turns out the source of the problem is that Trinidad is setting up a custom HttpServletResponse wrapper on the JSF ExternalContext during an Ajax request. This wrapper essentially blocks any calls to setContentType on the response (so that the JSP rendering will not reset the ContentType to "text/html" after Trinidad has already set it up to be "text/xml"). Spring Faces was not managing this custom response correctly, so it was getting thrown away before render time. FlowFacesContext now correctly preserves a custom response object during the course of a request, and this fixes the higher-level problem with Trinidad.
